quote: Look, save your energy.  We'll have    you out of there as soon as possible.    (muttering under his     breath)   I hope.
Try re-routing the power coupling...
Mister O'Brien...
(to repair crew;     ignoring the tap.)   ... See if you can activate the    interlock servos.
Mister O'Brien...

Captain, Jaheel, those people have    been stuck in that air lock for over    an hour.  Now if you'll just wait    until we get that door opened, I'll    be happy to discuss any problem you    might have.
But I've already been waiting two    days for your people to readjust my    ship's antimatter flow converter.
I'm afraid we've fallen a bit behind    in our maintenance schedule.

I'm not interested in hearing excuses.     I have a shipment of Tamen Sasheer    waiting to be delivered to Largo    Five, and I'll need to do better    than warp one to get there before it    spoils.
I'll try to get a repair crew on it    before the end of the day.  Now that's    the best I can do.
Your best, Mister O'Brien, hardly    seems good enough.
Dax to O'Brien.
O'Brien here.
Can you spare a minute, Chief.  I    have a little problem here at the    lab.
On my way.
Thanks for coming, Chief.
What are you doing out here?
Have you checked the EPS convertor?
Yes.  First thing.
How about the intensity grid?
It's fine.
Then it's probably the secondary    phase modulator.  We had trouble    with them last week in the main power    core.
This should do it.
Anything else I can do for you?
The navigational computer hasn't    been working reliably for three days.     I ask for the star charts of the    Argosian sector and the Glessene    sector comes up instead.
Uh-huh.
That's when I can even coax the system    on line.
Try it now.
That's more like it.
You look like you could use some
Who has time for sleep... ?
Coffee.
I'd settle for five minutes of peace    and quiet.
Chief, I thought you were going to    fix the replicators.
You're absolutely right, Sir.  I    knew I'd forgotten something.  Can't    have the operations chief sitting    around daydreaming when there's work    to be done, can we?  I'll get right    on it.
Fix the Replicators, Chief... My    console's off line, Chief... I    should've transferred to a cargo    drone... no people, no complaints...
Hot coffee black, double sweet.
Tell me, Quark, am I mistaken or is    business a little slow today?
Slow?  It's been almost nonexistent    for the past three days.
Who knows, if things don't improve    you may have to close down altogether.
You'd like that, wouldn't you?
Let's just say that without you    around, my job would be considerably    easier.
Without me around you'd be forced to    find some other, poor innocent to    persecute.  Think about that while    you sit here gloating at my    misfortune.
Quark!
You call this Kohlanese stew?
If your meal isn't satisfactory I'm    sure we could exchange it for    something more to your liking.
Aren't you the least bit curious how    it tastes?
Oh no you don't.  You served it.     You're going to eat it.
All right.  That's enough.
You heard me.  Eat.
I said leave him alone.
Another satisfied customer.
It's these replicators.  If I don't    get them repaired soon, they'll    destroy my business.
Why not get O'Brien to fix them.  He    has the replicators on the command    level working perfectly.
I'm on his waiting list.  He assures    me he'll get to them as soon as he    can.
No telling when that will be.  The    Chief's a very busy man.
Computer... display a station layout.     Highlight locations of all repaired    replicators on the command level.
Information restricted to security    clearance five and above.  Please    enter security verification.
Clearance verified.
Here you go, Sir.  I think you'll    find it more to your liking.
Much appreciated, Mister O'Brien.
Don't mention it, Sir.  Unfortunately,    there are still plenty of replicators    around the station that need looking    after...
You all right, Chief?
Bit warm, that's all.  Environmental    controls must be acting up again.
Please send my regards to Mrs.    O'Brien.  Jake tells me she's a    wonderful teacher.
That's nice to hear, Sir.  She's    flower units about the lad herself.
Excuse me?
Sir?
What was that you just said?
She's quite fond of the lad herself.
Glad to hear it.
Very good, Sir.
Lieutenant Dax.
Ladies.
Hello, Lieutenant.
I'd forgotten how different it was.
How different what was?
Being female.  I haven't been one    for over eighty years.
All this attention.
I imagine it must take some getting    use to.
Actually I find it quite enjoyable.
Major Kira... Lieutenant Dax...
I'd be honored to have you join my    little party.  As my guests, of    course.
What's all this, Quark?  You cheat    your one-thousandth customer?

Who says Bajorans have no sense of    humor?    (pointing to the     activity taking place     behind him)   Actually we're celebrating the repair    of the bar's replicator system.       Perhaps I could interest you in a    nice double-whipped I'danian spice    pudding.
What do you think?
I think I'm due back at Ops.  But go    on, enjoy yourself.
Please, make yourself comfortable,    Lieutenant.  I did say a double    whipped spice pudding, didn't I?
It's lovely.  I almost hate to eat    it.
By all means, take the time to admire    its beauty... While I admire yours.
Chief... ?
(trying to cover, but     failing)   How can I help you, Major?
You're the one who could use a little    help.
I'm fine, really.
I guess this isn't a good time to    tell you the number three Turbolift    has broken down again.

I'm joking, Chief.    (Note: From here on     dialogue spoken by     characters with     aphasia will appear     as gibberish in the     script.  A translation     will be provided     upon request, but it     would probably be     more effective if     the actors really     were unable to     communicate.)
Major.  Cat's lark pepper.
What?
Let birds go further loose maybe.     Shout easy play.
Chief, you're not making any sense.
Round the turbulent quick.
Close the reverse harbor.
Ankle try sound reset gleaming?
Dinner to bug.  When.
Chief... wait...
Computer continue neural imaging    scan.  Stimulate visual cortex.
All visual responses normal.
Computer begin auditory stimuli.
No physiological damage.  All brain    functions within normal parameters.
Nurse, pull up Mister O'Brien's neuro-   physiological history.
Yes, Doctor.
What is it?  What's he writing?
Flame the dark true salt.
Please, Chief, have a seat.
Way link complete.  Way link.
What's wrong with him?

He appears to be suffering from a    form of aphasia.  It's a perceptual    dysfunction in which aural and visual    stimuli are incorrectly processed by    the brain.  His actual thinking hasn't    been affected.  But he's incapable    of expressing himself or understanding    others.
Strike limits victory frosted wake.     Simple hesitation.
I'm not sure I follow you, Doctor.     You say Mister O'Brien is aphasic,    but all of his tests come up negative.
Isn't aphasia typically associated    with some kind of cranial trauma?
Yes.  It can occur as a result of a    stroke or blow to the head.  But    there's no evidence of that here.
Have you checked the medical library    for precedents?
And re-checked.  Nothing so far.
Have you any theories?
Not yet.
Find one.       Major, get hold of the Chief's    personal duty log.
I want to know where he's been and    what he's done for the past fifty-   two hours.
I've already examine it, Commander.     He's been all over this station.
Retrace his steps.  See what you    come up with.       Dax, you will temporarily assume    Mister O'Brien's duties.
Yes... I'll...
Is there a problem, Lieutenant?
Lieutenant.
I'm sorry, Benjamin, but... I'm unable    to... foolish assembled regal...    control weather.

Commander, spontaneous development    of aphasia is virtually impossible.     But we saw Lieutenant Dax become    aphasic before our eyes.  That told    me we were dealing with a disease    that only mimics aphasia.  So I ran    a full neuro-synaptic comparison of    Dax and O'Brien.       And found this in the temporal lobes    of both patients.
A virus?

It imposes itself within established    synaptic pathways and then randomly    reroutes them.  For example, when I    look at this...       ... a process occurs in my brain which    connects this stimulus to the word    "tricorder."  The virus disrupts    that process.
I'd see the tricorder but I would    say something ridiculous like...    window.
Exactly.
Doctor, I think you better get over    here.
Doctor, I want this station put under    emergency quarantine immediately.
Quark, what is going on here?
What's it look like?
It looks like business as usual.     But that's impossible, because all    shops and business have been closed    until further notice.
Except, of course, for essential    station operations.
For which this place hardly qualifies.
I don't think they would agree.     This quarantine has everyone on    edge, Constable.  Would you deprive    them of a little harmless diversion?
They'd be safer in their quarters.
Quark, that Kohlanese stew...    magnificent.
Fortunately my assistant, Rom, was    able to fix the replicators.
Yes, very fortunate.
Jake!
I expected you home an hour ago.
Sorry.  I was over at Nog's.
Dad, about this quarantine, it's    going to be okay, isn't it?
It's just a precaution.  Nothing    more.
I wish I shared your confidence    Commander.
Go on home, son.  I'll see you at    dinner.
Captain Jaheel, all visitors have    been confined to their ships.
Believe me, there is no place I'd    rather be.
Then what are you doing here?
Searching for you.  Commander, I    officially request permission to    leave this station.
Request denied.
But none of my crew has been affected    by this virus of yours, and unless I    depart at once my entire cargo will    be ruined...
Captain, I suggest you return to    your ship.  Now.
Please... I don't want to get sick.
I'm sorry, but until we find a cure    for this thing no one's going    anywhere.
Let's start with one Ferengi    Stardrifter, please.  Extra strong.
I thought the front wheels were    sticking a bit.
Unauthorized access to crew quarters    is a crime, Quark.       You could have just asked to use the    replicators.
There's an old Ferengi saying, "Never    ask when you can take."    (trying to hide his     annoyance)   How did you figure it out, anyway?
You claimed Rom fixed your    replicators.
So?
Rom's an idiot.  He couldn't fix a    straw if it was bent.
You're right.  He is an idiot.  Remind    me to get rid of him tomorrow.
Based on the levels of the virus    found in the patients' blood, I believe    it's being absorbed through ingestion.
You're saying it's in our food?
That's not possible.  All the food    on the station is replicated and all    the replicators use bio-filters.     They automatically screen out    contaminants, including viruses.
Major, I have analyzed samples from    all over the station.  All of the    food on the command level is    contaminated with the virus.
But all of us here have eaten from    those replicators.  How come we're    not aphasic?
This virus is highly adaptable.  Its    gestation period seems to vary within    each individual.

According to O'Brien's duty log the    last thing he did before become    aphasic was fix the command level    replicators.  But I had a repair    crew inspect the site.  They found    nothing suspicious.
Look again.  Closer.
Let's shut down the command level    replicators.  At the very least we    can contain this thing.
I'm not sure that's going to do it,    sir.  I've been getting aphasic    patients from all over the station...
But how is that possible...
You can thank Quark.
I caught him using a replicator in    one of the vacant crew quarters.  He    was producing his entire menu out of    there.
And contaminating all his customers.
If this virus is present in a large    enough segment of the population, it    could mean...
What is it, Doctor?
I just took an air sample.
The virus?
It's mutated into an airborne variety.
Which means?
Which means the whole station is    infected.

Station log Stardate 46423.7.  Nearly    sixty percent of DS Nine's population    has now contracted the aphasia virus.     We are advising all incoming ships    to maintain their distance from the    station until further notice.
I found it inside the replicator's    pattern generator.
O'Brien must have accidently triggered    it when he repaired the system.

According to Bashir, it introduced    an anomalous programming sequence    into the materialization subroutine.     In effect it built the virus directly    into the replicated food at a    molecular level.
So what we have here is sabotage.
Cardassian sabotage.
How can you be sure?
It has a diboridium core for a power    source.  That's Cardassian technology.
Bashir to Sisko.
Sisko here.
I think you'd better get down here    to the Infirmary, Commander.
On my way.
You wanted to see me, Doctor?
Jake?
It's okay, son.  It's okay.  I'm    here.
Left become better control entire    hope.
We've converted some empty crew    quarters into a hospital ward.  He'll    be well looked after.
I'll take him there myself.
Commander, when you have a moment...    I've found something I'd like to    show you.
Money... hand... mine... give.
Well, Quark, I see even you couldn't    weasel your way clear of this one.
You underestimate the Ferengi immune    system, Commander.  I'm merely here    to visit some of my less fortunate    customers...
To make certain they're not faking    the illness to avoid paying their    bills.
No one's that devious Quark.
I am.
You... gold... owe... me.
We're doing everything possible.
I'll be back as soon as I can.
The virus is synthetic, Commander.     Its nucleotide sequence is too    perfect.  It's clearly not natural.
You're saying the Cardassians    genetically engineered this thing?

That's what I thought at first.  But    I've studied Cardassian genetic    engineering.  They always build    distinctive monoclonial links into    their DNA.  This virus has none of    those features.
All right, then who made it.
That's what I wanted to find out.     So I referenced all known DNA    construction techniques in the    Federation records...
This protein series was the key.  It    indicates that...
Doctor, who created this virus?
The Bajorans, sir.  I believe this    must have been a terrorist plot to    sabotage the Cardassians while they    were here.
The energy decay of this power core    indicates that it dates back to the    building of the station.
That's eighteen years ago.  I suppose    the Bajoran underground could have    smuggled it aboard during    construction.       Before I took over as head of    security.
But why would the underground go to    all the trouble of planting a booby    trap and then not set it off?
Maybe they forgot.
More likely they were captured or    killed before they could release it.
We need to find out who created the    virus.       You're our best hope.
Eighteen years is a long time.
Besides, even if she finds this    person... that's no guarantee he can    help us.
We just have to hope he remembers    the antidote.
That's assuming he ever bothered to    create one.
... Had to be someone in the    underground familiar with genetic    engineering.
Eighteen years ago... sounds like    something Dekon Elig might have    thought up.
How can I find him?
Last I heard he was in a Cardassian    prison.
Where was he being held?
The Velos Seven Internment Camp.     But that was nine years ago.
And you have no idea where he is    now?       Think, Galis.  This is important.
I'm sorry Kira, but it was all so    long ago.
Roll linger when life.  Roll linger    when.
What is it, Jake?
Other support strong courage.
He's running a high fever.
Open way long.  Openway.
Doctor, we have an emergency here in    the crew quarters.
I'll be right there.
How is he, Doctor?
Not good, I'm afraid.  It seems the    virus has attacked his autonomic    nervous system.
Can he be stabilized?
He hasn't responded to neural    stimulation.  I've given him thirty    c.c.'s of corophizine to avoid    secondary infection, but so far I've    been unable to lower his fever.
What are his chances?
Unless I find some way to counteract    the virus, he'll be dead in twelve    hours.
(gently; knows Bashir     is doing his best)   Have you made any progress?

No... I've tried base pair de-   stabilizers, sequential disruption,    nothing seems to affect it.       Sir, I have seven other aphasic    patients displaying the same symptoms    as O'Brien here.  And I'm afraid    it's only the beginning.
Keep searching, Doctor.  And let's    hope Major Kira can find whoever's    responsible for creating this virus.
I'd like to meet that person myself.     This virus is a work of genius.
I'll try and arrange it for you.
Link established with the Bajoran    Archival Records.
Locate files on Velos Seven Internment    camp.
Ready.
Do you show a record of an inmate    named Dekon Elig?
Affirmative.
Biographical data...
Dekon Elig.  Geneticist...
Former member of the Higa Metar Sect    of the Bajoran underground.  Killed    while attempting escape Stardate    39355.  Certificate of Death on file.
No need to ask how you're doing.
I'm chasing after ghosts.
You have twelve hours to catch one.
And then?
People start dying.
Computer, display Dekon Elig's    Certificate of Death.
Identify signature of witness.
Certificate of Death was witnessed    by Surmak Ren, Bajoran Medical    Assistant.
Show me biographical data on Surmak    Ren.

Doctor Surmak Ren.  Former member of    the Higa Metar sect of the Bajoran    underground.  Repatriated to Bajor    upon closing of the Velos Seven    Internment Camp, Stardate 46302.     Current status... unknown.
Dabo!
Having any luck?
I haven't won a spin in hours.       Care to place a friendly wager?       If it's your reputation you're    thinking about... no one need ever    know.
It has nothing to do with my    reputation.  The truth is I've    never...       ... learned the game.
That's correct.
No wonder you always look so bored.       The rules are quite simple, actually.     I would be happy to teach them to    you...
Some other time perhaps.  Sisko needs    me in Ops.       And with the entire security force    stricken with aphasia, that leaves    the promenade in a very vulnerable    position.
How... unfortunate.
Consider it a warning, Quark.  Because    I'm holding you personally responsible    for anything that turns up missing.     Is that understood?
Perfectly.
Dabo!
Computer, analyze test sample thirty-   seven delta.  Detail effects on viral    containment.
Working...       Analysis complete.  Sample thirty-   seven delta ineffective...
... viral protein sheath is    unaffected... Nucleotide sequence    remains intact...
Computer... Replay morning.
Command unclear.  Please repeat.
Glass lunch judge a bin to let it...
Command unclear.  Please repeat.
Computer, establish link with the    Bajoran Medical Index for Northwestern    District...
Link established.
Access all information on Doctor    Surmak Ren.
There are no records matching that    name.
Try the Northeastern District.  Same    search.
Doctor Surmak Ren, currently serving    as Chief Administrator of the Ilvian    Medical Complex.
Computer, open a channel to the Ilvian    Medical Complex... Administrators    office.
This is Doctor Surmak.  And you are?
Major Kira Nerys.  Bajoran liaison    to Deep Space Nine.
Ah yes, the old Cardassian mining    station.  How can I help you?
That depends.
On what?
On whether or not you helped Dekon    Elig plant an aphasia virus here,    eighteen years ago.
I have no idea what you're talking    about.
Look here, Sisko.  I'm a security    officer.  A good one.  But that    doesn't make me qualified to help    you run station operations.
You're probably right, Constable...
But as you can see, you're all I've    got.
Commander, I think I found our    scientist.
Does he have an antidote?
I don't know.  He broke the connection    the minute I mentioned the virus.
Major, you mind telling me where    you're going?
To continue my conversation with    Doctor Surmak.
Major, I can't allow you to break    quarantine.  We can't risk spreading    the virus to Bajor.
I'm well aware of that, Commander.     As a matter of fact, I don't intend    to step foot on the planet.
Better let her go, Sisko.
She's all we've got.
I just hope there's someone left to    greet her when she returns.
Jake!
How's it going, fella?

I've missed you, son.  I know things    don't look too good right now.  But    they'll get better.  You have to    believe that.  Because... I'm not    going to lose you, Jake.  You hear    me?  I'm not going to lose you.
You better take a look at this... We    have activity on Docking Port Five.     I think a ship's about to depart.
Docking Port Five?  That's Jaheel's    ship.  Put him on screen.
Captain, your ship has not been    cleared for departure.  The mooring    clamps are locked.  And I don't intend    to release them.
I suggest you change your mind.  I'm    taking aft thrusters to one half.
Captain, cut your engines before you    rip your ship apart.
He's not reducing power.
Jaheel, I'm ordering you to stand    down.
Your orders are no concern of mine.     My entire crew has been confined to    your hospital.  I must leave now    while I can still function.
Look, I understand you're frightened.     But believe me, you're better off    here.  You don't want to be out there    alone and get hit by the virus.
Don't worry about me.  I'm fine and    I intend to stay that way.
Damn.
What's wrong?
There's too much stress on the mooring    clamps.  They're not retracting.
His aft isolation plate buckled.
The main power core's been ruptured.     If the internal fuel cells collapse    the whole ship will explode.
And take half the docking ring with    it.
Computer, isolate a comline to the    Ilvian Medical Complex.     Administrator's office.
Line isolated.
Scan the office for lifeforms.
One life form present.
Lock on and stand by to transport.
This is Doctor Surmak.
Hello again, Doctor.  Just wanted to    make sure you were in your office.
I have nothing to say to you...
Welcome aboard.
This is outrageous.  I demand you    return me to my office immediately.
Relax, Doctor.  You won't be gone    long.
Where are you taking me?
To the space station.
Try to re-establish visual contact    with Jaheel's ship.
No response.  His com lines are down.
Bypass communications through his    secondary grid.  See if you can switch    to external pickups.
Got it.
His fire control systems don't appear    to be working.
We have about fifteen minutes before    the fuel cells collapse.
I hope you feel better than you look.
It must be that damn virus.       This is Sisko.
Any station personnel who can    understand what I'm saying should    come to Ops immediately.  We need    help up here.       We have to get that ship away from    the station.
Why don't we explode the mooring    clamps.  The blast should push the    ship away from the docking ring.
We'll have to get down there and    blow them manually.
I'll do it.
All right... you can cross barrels    all job appalled.
What was that you...
Bread the arrive seen earlier.
Oh, I see...
Major, this is kidnapping.  Turn    this ship around or I swear you'll    spend the rest of your life in Kran-   Tobol Prison.
Fine.  But first we need your help.     The aphasia virus is spreading through    the station.
But why come to me.
You helped create the virus didn't    you.

No!  I had practically nothing to do    with it.  Dekon Elig created the    virus.  I was merely his medical    assistant.       It all seems like a life time ago.     I was only with the underground six    months before we were captured.       I am not responsible for this.
I'm not looking to place blame.  All    I want is the antidote.
But I don't know of any antidote.     If Dekon made one, he never told me.
Look, all I know is I have a station    full of dying people, and you're the    closest thing to an expert on this    virus.
I sympathize, Major.  But I don't    think I can help you.
All right, then how about helping    yourself?
Meaning what?
(leaning toward him     for emphasis)   Meaning I've been infected with your    virus, Doctor.  So now you're infected    too.
To anyone who can hear me... this is    Odo.  Sisko's infected.  I could    really use some help in Ops.
Do I detect a note of panic in your    voice?
Quark, am I to believe you're    volunteering to help?
Who said anything about volunteering?     But we can haggle over price later.       Now how may I be of service?
I need to get to Docking Port Five,    now.  That ship is going to explode    in five minutes.
I'll beam you over.
Relax.  I served on a Ferengi    freighter for eight years.
(carefully, studying     panel)   I must have witnessed this procedure    hundreds of times.
Witnessed?  You mean to say you never    handled the controls yourself?
Energizing.
Kira to Ops.  Approaching landing    pad seven.  Request clearance to    initiate docking procedure.
Welcome back Major.  I could use    some help up here.
Quark what are you doing in Ops?
First thing I need to see is your    Doctors' viral characterization    research.
He was beginning to develop an    antidote series.  Let's take a look    at that.
I'll be in Ops.  If you need me use    the string...
... impact lots show red intense.
I think you'd better sit down, Major.
Dog fellow distance.
Tell me about it.
Odo, that ship's going to explode in    one minute.
scene: 91   INT. OPS - TIGHT ON QUARK AT OPERATIONS TABLE

quote: Virum protein sheath... uh-huh...    Nucleotide sequence... yes...       That's right, it's an adaptive    synaptic inhibitor... Dekon was    brilliant, there's no doubt of that.
Forty seconds.
Thirty seconds.  Hurry.
Twenty seconds.
I know.  I know.
Quark to Odo.  You still with us?
Try not to sound too disappointed.
Now, about that little matter of my    hazard pay...
Your doctor came very close to finding    the antidote himself.  The answer is    in a progressive base substitution.
Now I just need to take a blood    sample.
Station log, Stardate 46425.8.  We're    continuing to administer Doctor    Surmak's antidote throughout the    station.  Things are slowly returning    to normal.
Good to have you back, Chief.
Thank you, sir.
Hot coffee, black.
O'Brien... !
